citations.narrative:
There is closed-up kennel shift doors where the trim has been chewed or chipped away exposing the wood beneath the
trim in six enclosures housing 12 puppies. These are the same six enclosures identified in the last inspection. Facilities
not kept in good repair or have sharp edges may result in an injury to the animals or create a disease hazard. Housing
facilities must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound, kept in good repair and protect the animals
from injury.

The facility has not maintained a record of treatment and care for a litter of three puppies currently under treatment for a
cough. Without proper documentation, it is difficult to determine the efficacy of a treatment plan. A proper medical record
includes the date the problem was found, a description of the problem, the name and frequency of medications used,
examination findings, test results, plans for treatment and care, and treatment procedures performed must be recorded
and a copy kept for review during inspection by APHIS officials. Correct by ensuring all records of any treatments for
problems identified in the dogs are recorded and maintained.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Jennifer Walker, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.1(a)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There is closed-up kennel shift doors where the trim has been chewed or chipped away exposing the wood beneath the 
trim in six enclosures housing 12 puppies. These are the same six enclosures identified in the last inspection. Facilities 
not kept in good repair or have sharp edges may result in an injury to the animals or create a disease hazard. Housing 
facilities must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound, kept in good repair and protect the animals 
from injury. 
3.13(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility has not maintained a record of treatment and care for a litter of three puppies currently under treatment for a 
cough. Without proper documentation, it is difficult to determine the efficacy of a treatment plan. A proper medical record 
includes the date the problem was found, a description of the problem, the name and frequency of medications used, 
examination findings, test results, plans for treatment and care, and treatment procedures performed must be recorded 
and a copy kept for review during inspection by APHIS officials. Correct by ensuring all records of any treatments for 
problems identified in the dogs are recorded and maintained. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Jennifer Walker, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
